e4: Changing to a completely unbiased policy immediately removes pre-existing understanding, possibly creating short-term market volatility and uncertainty. A potential solution is establishing a transparent framework that addresses public investor communication needs while minimizing unexpected earnings fluctuations in line with SEC guidelines.
e5: An ethical reporting policy needs transparency and honesty, setting clear expectations with forward-looking goals while acknowledging past discrepancies.  A true reflection of underlying business conditions is paramount to maintain trust, both with investors, regulators, and long-term stakeholders within the company.
e6: It is crucial to understand the long-term effects of both a complete change and a partial policy shift on investor behavior.  Understanding investor expectations about future performance changes, not simply disclosing current biases, will provide a more robust framework for navigating ethical reporting.
